description: time to move to anything else...from mozilla maintenance enforcing reviewal of your privacy to preset "firefox sees all your $%%^ buttons in settings you guys are pure, absurd, trash.
The browser and wider FF ecosystem are excellent, and are a great privacy-focused alternative to other vendors.
I can browse the internet with it. Occasionally glitches, but easily fixed. Functional, but not especially amazing or anything.

It's evolved over time to become something... not quite right. I'm starting to look for alternatives.

Default security settings are lousy (e.g. captive portal comes enabled).

It's integrated with Google APIs; so much for users' privacy. Mozilla is increasingly becoming part of the surveillance economy.

Shipping it with Google as the default search engine, along with Amazon, eBay, and Bing... come on now. Stop overspending as a non-profit, and you wouldn't need to use these unethical practices to generate revenue streams.

"Telemetry" is just a euphemism for "we're masquerading as helpful, but really we want to collect data about you". Similar situation with OSCP.

For all their marketing, they don't really deliver either security or privacy.

Firefox will eventually need to be forked and modified, or replaced with a browser that respects the rights of users. 

Also, they're conducting a totally unfounded and misleading smear campaign against Richard Stallman (He's a good man, but he made too many powerful enemies by speaking truth to power. He created the GNU project and the FSF for f**ks sake. We wouldn't have Debian, or essentially any other distro, without his pioneering work. He's not a misogynist, racist, sexist, etc... that's all BS. He realizes his mistakes and apologizes, that is a sign of great devotion to personal growth. When he's gone, his work will outlast any opportunistic character attacks made possible by the current zeitgeist). 

Top management at Mozilla has seemingly been corrupted by FAMGAN (Facebook, Amazon, Microsoft, Google, Apple, Netflix). Money talks.
summary: Used to be perfect... not so much any more
